ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 6-7 hours
2hrs
7 hrs
3 hours
Exempted from this class
Approx. 3 hours
At least five hours per week
About 3 hours outside of classwork to complete the assignments and review.
N/A - technically not enrolled in this course. Passed out.
3-5 hours
4 hours per week

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: It was an excellent course.Strenghts: Provided important tools for understanding markets.-was taught in a very clear and engaging way-had an appropriate courseload/difficulty-exams tested indepth knowledge of the materialWeaknesses:-transitions from topic to topic was at times weak
Good classMy first intro to economics.. loved itconcepts explained in a terse and practical examples given to aid understanding
Great! I love this course

This course would be better suited for twice a week and taught more as a true introductory class and leave more time to discuss actual economic issues affecting health care. The instructor was very responsive to feed back but he has a hard time teaching economics at an introductory level.
Interesting subject matter, instructor improved a lot and the subject got easier over the course of the semester.
Strength: The material gives a good understanding of the core concepts of microeconomics.

Very interesting, especially for those with no background in econ. However, the first half of the course is also a bit challenging for those with no background in economics. It would be helpful to have a textbook and fewer "fun" articles the first few weeks to gain a solid basis before moving forward.

It is a great course. It gives a good presentation of the basics of microeconomics and applies the principles to health care. We got all of the tools we needed to assess healthcare from an economic perspective. The weekly homework assignments were challenging, and helped to clarify what you know and what yo don't know. I think it gave me skills that I will use throughout my career.
The material is a bit hard to comprehend if you have not taken economics.

Weakness- Doesn't always progress in logical order and lecture can be a bit disconnected. It also assumes that everyone has an economics background. There could be more time spent on the application of economic to health care.
Exempted from this class

Strengths:Covers a wide range of economic concepts.Places concepts into the health care context.Real life examples were able to highlight the practical relevance.Weaknesses:It might be helpful to provide more mathematical context.Suggestions:That said, students might not be equally prepared to take advantage from a more mathematical presentation. Thus, a general improvement opportunity is to provide a mathematical compendium prior to starting the MPH so that everyone is somewhat on the same level. Complaints about not having been prepared mathematically are a recurring theme among students from biostats to economics. So this might be helpful as a general comment.

The course and instructor were excellent. Particular strengths include his accessability for answering questions and his patience, both of which show he really cares whether his students are learning or not.
Great introduction course. Relevant to Health Care practitioners.

The course is critical for the students and should be spread out to having class twice a week instead of once. There is a lot of material to cover, and I feel that I didn't take away as much as I would like to. Professor McKee was very perceptive to the students' concerns but sometimes had a hard time explaining simple points. Nonetheless, he spent extra time with the students to fully gather his thoughts and made sure to answer any questions.
This is a well designed course that move at an appropriate pace.
N/A - technically not enrolled in this course. Passed out.

strength: good for econ beginners, very basic principles taughtweakness: the instructor cannot make himself clear lots of times, he will get confused himself in the middle of explanation of a concept, which is quite disturbing for students.
The course provided a great overview of economics for healthcare professionals. Great examples were used, and the lectures were very interesting and helpful.
useful and easy to catch

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Douglas McKee  The instructor was lively, engaging, clear and understanding. One of the best taught classes I've taken at Yale.

Instructor: Douglas McKee  Good instructorhas a lot of knowledge on the subject, probably is time constrained in class... But if approached in office hours with questions, provides depth of insights.Facilitates learning, with examples both in class and on HW..
Instructor: Douglas McKee  He's great! details oriented and very nice to students

Instructor: Douglas McKee  The instructor is very responsive to feedback and he is enthusiastic and interested in his students. He also improved as the semester went on. He tries very hard to be helpful. He isn't the greatest at explaining basic economics concepts in class though.

Instructor: Douglas McKee  Very knowledgeable, friendly and approachable. Initially difficult to follow because he presented too much material, but that got easier and he restructured the class to cut down on the excess information. Very receptive to feedback, and willing to accomodate students' requests.
Instructor: Douglas McKee  Very enthusiastic and fair istructor.

Instructor: Douglas McKee  Prof. McKee is great- very sensitive to the level of econ background for everyone in the course, and wonderful lectures second half of the course (first half some of the lectures were a little overwhelming...) Would be ideal to have the course twice a week- a few more hours at the beginning of the semester would have been great. Loved the course!

Instructor: Douglas McKee  Doug gives great presentations, and uses a lot of examples, which is exceptionally helpful to understanding the information. He was easily approachable and answered questions well.
Instructor: Douglas McKee  Doug is very knowledgeable about the subject matter.
Instructor: Douglas McKee  Best instructor of the semester, hands down. great
Instructor: Douglas McKee  Strengths- engaging, knowledgeable, provides easy to understand examples.Weakness- assumes students have at least a base in Microeconomics.
Instructor: Douglas McKee  Exempted from this class
Instructor: Douglas McKee  See previous answer
Instructor: Douglas McKee  Very engaging, making subject interesting for people without any background in economics. Accessible, easy to ask questions.
Instructor: Douglas McKee  Professor McKee is a very personable professor who genuinely cares for the students. He is open to office hours and responds quickly to emails with a cordial tone.

Instructor: Douglas McKee  The professor did an excellent job accommodating the wide variety of backgrounds in economics possessed by the students. He kept the lectures interesting and is an engaging lecturer. He is very accessible and really made himself available to students.
Instructor: Douglas McKee  N/A - technically not enrolled in this course. Passed out.

Instructor: Douglas McKee  I wish he could make himself more clear, thinking of good examples prior to class rather than struglling with coming up with one in the middle of a class. Be more prepared, especially with the quesitons students may pop up.

Instructor: Douglas McKee  The instructor was interactive with students and provided a great overview of economic analysis on market supply/demand within US healthcare system. His powerpoint slides were very informative and thorough. More examples and problem sets are recommended;however, weekly problem sets were very helpful.
Instructor: Douglas McKee  good

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: The TA did an excellent job getting the HW graded and answering additional questions about the content.

Kimi was nicevery very flexibleeven added and extra office hour every week to accommodate students who could not make it MondayProvided good insights on the subjecther examples on the subject were very good...a great TALove you Kimi...
TA is nice!

Kimi was very accessible and accomodating--more so than most of the TAs this semester. My suggestion for the future would be for the TA to actually do the problem sets before office hours because more than once, she guided us through things the wrong way and then realized it was wrong and started over. It made things confusing and wasted time. However, even more so than that, I would recommend that an actual economics grad student be the TA because they can help with basic questions and concepts that Doug isn't always equipped to explain. Then students are hearing the same information in a different way.
Kimberly Kushner - excellent
Kimi Kushner - Excellent: friendly, approachable, knowledgeable on the subject matter and very helpful. A+!
TA was excellent, provided good feedback.
Kimi was a great support for us this semester- without her help a few weeks in the beginning we would have been lost!
The TA was Kimi Kushner. I didn't really interact with her, but she did provide a review before the midterm that was helpful and ansered some questions during lecture.
Kimi was a great resource and led a very well-informed review session
Exempted from this class
Kimi kushner was terrific. Like prof mckee, accessible and patient.
Kimi is absolutely wonderful. Definite teaching talent! Found TA sessions very helpful in my studies.

The TA was excellent for this course. She really understood the material and created a reference base of notes just in case she stumbled upon a tough concept. She provided guidance through the course and allowed the students to talk out problems during office hours. By far, she really helped clarify a lot of the confusing topics.
N/A - technically not enrolled in this course. Passed out.
Very few input from TA except the grading of homework.
TA was excellent and very helpful.
not easily accessible

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would definitely recommend you take this if you have an interest in learning about markets, or health economics or economics in general.

Nice class...the concept of economics will be very clear. good understanding of the basicsubject matter, which is critical to understanding anything aheadinstructor is nice, will make every attempt to go slow and ensure that everyone is on the same page...Even explains stuff from the previous class to freahen up and establish continuitygood class...
This course provide basic economic knowledge and prepare you for advanced electives. It's great! have a nice connection between econ and healthcare.
It is a very quick intro to economics where you learn an abbreviated version of the basics. You would probably get more out of a true intro to microeconomics class.
Yes - material is very useful for students of health policy and those interested in health economics in general.
A good course that has the purpose of providing you with a solid foundation in terms of microeconomics.
A little dense in the beginning, especially for those with no microeconomics background, but overall great. Second half of the course very interesting (and second to last lecture is fabulous!).
It is the perfect course to learn about economics within a healthcare context. I would recommend that everyone interested in understanding the economic context of healthcare take this course.
This course is a good economics course however, I would recommend purchasing a text book for supplemental information
Yes, I would recommend this class.
Exempted from this class
The syllabus addressed a wide range of economic techniques and principals and placed them in a helpful manner into the context of health care. Overall a very interesting course.
Very good introductory course. Would like to learn more about the subject.

I would say this course is rigorous but doable. The content is a lot and the information is very applicable to everyday life. Overall, I would highly recommend this course, but just be aware that the extra TA office hours will be very helpful!

This was an excellent overview of the basic principles of microeconomics. The course gives you the tools necessary to think and evaluate problems like an economist. The course is engaging and the professor is excellent. I would recommend this course even for non-HPA/HMP students.
N/A - technically not enrolled in this course. Passed out.
I would not recommend this class. It is probably more efficient to self-study and take the econ class taught by Prof. Susan Busch.
I would highly recommend the course to other students who need the introduction to economics and are thinking of pursuing healthcare professionals.
yes
